Welcome to SimpleTwitter’s documentation!¶

Contents:

  • What is SimpleTwitter
  • Requirements and Installation

  • Running the Application
    • As a Console Application
    • As a Web Application
  • API Documentation

What is SimpleTwitter¶

SimpleTwitter is a console application, a web application and a library for searching for recent tweets. It displays the most recent tweets matching your search query. In console mode, it refreshes periodically with new tweets.

Requirements and Installation¶

SimpleTwitter requires some additional packages, namely Flask, requests and click. These should be installed automatically together with the package. Before using the application, you need to configure it with your Twitter API key and secret. See Obtaining Twitter API keys for more information.

Install the application using Test PyPi:

pip install -i https://testpypi.python.org/pypi --extra-index-url https://pypi.python.org/pypi simpletwitter

Obtaining Twitter API keys¶

In order to use the application, providing your personal API key and API secret is necessary. This manual assumes you have a valid Twitter account at disposal.

  1. Navigate to apps.twitter.com
  2. Click “Create New App”
  3. Fill in arbitrary name that nobody else uses (make something up), description and a URL (anything except of example.org) You don’t have to fill the callback URL
  4. Take your Consumer API key and Consumer Secret from the Keys and Token Access tab.
  5. Place the keys in the following format to an ini file where no unauthorised person can access it. Keep in mind: your API key is like your password.

Example twitter_keys.ini:

[twitter]
api_key = YOUR_KEY_HERE
api_secret = YOUR_SECRET_HERE

Running the Application¶

As a Console Application¶

Run

simpletwitter console --keys twitter_keys.ini konvalinka

to get latest tweets from the world of flora (and fauna in the Prague area). To restrict keys for certain language, use e.g.

simpletwitter console --keys twitter_keys.ini --lang cs konvalinka

The language code should follow the ISO standards.

You can also specify how many tweets to return or how often to check for new tweets (using --tweet_count and --refresh_time, respectively). The refresh time takes integers (seconds) as an argument.

As a Web Application¶

Run

simpletwitter web --keys twitter_keys.ini

This will start the server bundled with Flask. You should see something like

* Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/ (Press CTRL+C to quit]

Open the address and voilà, you are there. The user interface is simple, but powerful (haha). This allows you to search for tweets quickly.

API Documentation¶

The following part documents the public API of the application:

simpletwitter.read_tweets(search, tweet_count=5, lang=None, session=None, api_key='', api_secret='')¶

Read tweets matching given criteria.

Search for tweets in specified language, provided your api_key and api_secret tokens.

Parameters:
  • search – The string you want to search for
  • tweet_count – The maximum number of tweets returned.
  • lang – The language you want to filter (only one supported). Use the ISO language codes like cs, en
  • session – If you already have a session returned from a previous call of the function, you can reuse it to prevent handshaking again
  • api_key – API key retrieved from Twitter
  • api_secret – API secret retrieved from Twitter
Returns:

Returns tuple (tweets, session). Tweets is a dictionary with structure specified in the Twitter API documentation, session is just an object you can pass next time to the function to save some resources.

Examples¶ 

>>> len(simpletwitter.read_tweets("python", tweet_count=2, api_key="blabla", api_secret="huhuhu"))
2
